column5: Haha, I did the same thing! I was like ¬´huh.. well I guess they can be considered a kind of brand as well.‚Äù üòÖ

I just fell in love so bad that my need to talk to them, get to know them, be close to them was stronger than my fear. That‚Äôs the only way I can describe it.

To be fair, at that point my childhood memories were still safely repressed, and I thought constant anxiety was normal, I was just autopiloting through life, fell in love, had no concept of consequences and nothing to lose.

I couldn‚Äôt function in my old job (too many people, horrible bosses, I was too dependent/replaceable, I never felt safe) so the labour and welfare administration is financially supporting me through a bachelor‚Äôs degree that will give me better work options, like a coder, so that I hopefully will have a job I can live with long term.

Edit: so I guess my advice would be to think about what an ideal job situation would be for you. For me, that would be 1) a job where I feel safe and needed, for that I need an education that‚Äôs in demand right now, 2) a job where I have to deal with a minimum of people in my day to day life & 3) a job that will pay me enough money to live a normal life, even if my mental health wouldn‚Äôt allow me to work full time. 

So for me I chose programming and economics, because it lets me work on the computer and not with people, it‚Äôs something that‚Äôs in demand (which is both good because it makes it easier to get a job, but also it makes me feel more valuable, which in turn makes it easier to stand up for myself), and it pays enough to make me feel safe. 

I also considered archive-work, storage, or lab-work.

Edit2: do not fall in the Amazon-storage-type jobs though. Humane bosses are extremely important for people like us (for everyone really). When in interviews ask questions about the work environment and company culture and stuff. 

I‚Äôm sorry I‚Äôm rambling, but I feel so strongly about this topic. My old job made me want to die every day. I felt so hopeless, worthless and replaceable and I never ever want to be in a situation like that ever again, and I don‚Äôt want anyone else to struggle like that either. We spend so much of our lives at work, it is SO important to have a safe environment at work.

Oh definitely! I am extremely sensitive to being told to do obvious things, which 100% comes from my mother who criticises everything I do or say, even now as an adult. It‚Äôs so bad that if my boyfriend asks me if I‚Äôve brushed my teeth I go complete zombie-mode, or instant anger, like I want to scream that I‚Äôm not an idiot or defend my intelligence in some way. My mother wasn‚Äôt even my main problem growing up, that was my father - but I guess it‚Äôs easier to think that he‚Äôs just mentally ill. She is capable of having real conversations, why can‚Äôt she treat me with respect?

I sometimes think I was so focused on the hurt my father caused and dealing with the aftermath of that, and so I haven‚Äôt really dealt with the pain my mother caused me. Recently I‚Äôve also noticed that she treats my father really disrespectfully as well. I mean, he is an asshole to her all the time, but again, she is often capable of rational though, why does she have to hurt him and push his buttons?

I‚Äôm not gonna lie, it took me years to get comfortable around them, some therapy, but I‚Äôm finally comfortable around them. I even went to a family gathering with them, WITHOUT my boyfriend there. I‚Äôm quite proud of that one. And in the end I don‚Äôt want my fears to stop me from being with my partner. I‚Äôm gonna be awkward and quiet for the rest of my life probably, I might as well be awkward around a SOs family too.

I‚Äôm so so sorry this happened to you. This was absolutely not your fault at all, this was your father‚Äôs fault, and his fault alone. You deserve to be safe and cared for and I wish I could help you.

I‚Äôm a student, but I chose a degree (computer programming) that will let me work without having to deal with a lot of new people everyday, because that makes my anxiety go through the roof. I also thought about what kind of degrees are needed in my area, so that it‚Äôll be easier for me to stand up for myself when I need to. I have previously been treated horribly by my bosses - in a field where they could easily replace me, and I never want to be in that position again. 

So not really answering your question, but my point is that if you really think about what you would be comfortable doing in the long run, and what you don‚Äôt want to deal with, picking the right path for you could give you a good career and good pay.

I‚Äôve thought about killing myself so many times, and it does not feel selfish in those moments, but it is. That‚Äôs just the nature of depression and feeling suicidal. You, not on purpose, reduce everyone else‚Äôs emotions to fit your view of yourself, tell yourself that you know better than them, that everyone would be better off without you etc, when that‚Äôs really not your place to decide. I understand if people can‚Äôt bare the pain anymore, but let‚Äôs not pretend it isn‚Äôt selfish. And where is the line between telling someone you‚Äôre gonna kill yourself, and threatening to kill yourself?

Things such as self diagnosing is a genuine problem, especially when it comes to personality disorders, as all humans have lots of the different symptoms for lots of things, without necessarily having any of the disorders. That‚Äôs just human nature. 

But when it comes to things such as anxiety and depression, I also find the gatekeep-y attitude from some people to be harmful. I avoided getting help for years and years because I didn‚Äôt want to offend anyone by thinking my issues were anything other than occasional sadness.

Therapy and medication has helped me. I am much, much better at making friends, and keeping them, now than I was before. I always, subconsciously, used to exclude myself out of fear of being excluded or rejected, being perceived as weird or clingy and other negative things. Going to therapy helped me understand myself more, helped me be kinder to myself, see my behaviour in a new perspective and have my feelings validated. 

I don‚Äôt think I could have done that on my own, therapy has been essential for me, but also anti anxiety meds to help take the edge off and make it easier to feel my feelings and reflect upon them and not let them become an explosion of anxiety the second I go to bed.

I love working out. It makes me feel strong and good about myself. It helps my depression and anxiety so much, and makes me feel more confident in my body. Sometimes I find it hard to get my ass off the couch, but once I get there, I love every second of it. I do hate cardio though, so I tend to not do that. I‚Äôm working on it though.

I was thinking I‚Äôd get a high score, but it turns out Christmas gifts and vacations don‚Äôt count. Makes it kind of telling how my mind works. (aka I got to go to Paris/whatever at 10 years old, so I had a great childhood and should stop being ungrateful and spoiled etc).

Don‚Äôt use the test to invalidate your own feelings/trauma you experienced. The fact that you had good experiences, but still ended up traumatised, says something about how bad the bad stuff must have actually been.

Is it possible that you might be projecting your own negative feelings about yourself onto others? 

I used to feel so excluded, but then I realised that I was the one pulling away, because I was scared of being rejected. I was terrified of letting people know I wanted to hang out with them. 

If I were to make friends, they would have to initiate it 100% of the time, for me to feel safe enough to let them know I also wanted to hang with them. But this isn‚Äôt fair to them or to me, and I had to really work on my feelings and thoughts about myself.
